overview.what: The Third Way network coordinates national consulting talent and donor capital to steer state party reforms.
overview.strategy: Deploy template reforms that look inclusive while consolidating decision-making inside consultant-run committees.
overview.why_now: The 2026 cycle forces organizers to choose between compliance with captured reforms or building alternative power.

tactics.name: Compliance capture
tactics.description: Install trusted operatives inside compliance offices so they can approve or deny grassroots plans at will.
examples: Hiring freezes until approved candidates surface
Parallel review tracks that reroute organizer paperwork

tactics.name: Narrative laundering
tactics.description: Frame the capture as modernization or inclusion work to blunt organizer criticism.
examples: Press releases announcing diversity task forces led by consultants
Earned media featuring national spokespeople over local leaders

tactics.name: Selective enforcement
tactics.description: Use compliance power to penalize Indigenous or reform caucuses for procedural missteps that party insiders routinely ignore.
examples: Rejecting delegate slates for minor formatting issues
Reopening credential challenges after votes are cast

organizer_questions: Who approved the consultants staffing your compliance offices?
Which national partners review your reform documents before they reach the state committee?
Where do donor reporting requirements conflict with grassroots accountability?
